LanguageData.VCE_Chirashizushi.label: chirashizushi bowl (simple)
LanguageData.VCE_Chirashizushi.description: A simple chirashizushi bowl made from a few ingredients. In Chirashizushi rice is served in a bowl and topped with a variety of raw fish and vegetable garnishes. It is commonly eaten because it is filling, fast and easy to make.
LanguageData.VCE_Norimaki.label: norimaki (simple)
LanguageData.VCE_Norimaki.description: Simple norimaki sushi made from a few ingredients. Norimaki are a type of sushi wrapped with seaweed.
LanguageData.VCE_Uramaki.label: uramaki (fine)
LanguageData.VCE_Uramaki.description: Complex uramaki sushi assembled with care from a wide selection of ingredients. Uramaki is a medium-sized cylindrical piece with two or more fillings, and it differs from other maki because the rice is on the outside and the nori seaweed inside.
LanguageData.VCE_Nigiri.label: nigiri (fine)
LanguageData.VCE_Nigiri.description: Complex nigiri sushi assembled with care from a wide selection of ingredients. Nigirizushi consists of an oblong mound of sushi rice that the chef presses between the palms of the hands to form an oval-shaped ball, and a topping (the neta) draped over the ball.
LanguageData.VCE_Temaki.label: temaki (lavish)
LanguageData.VCE_Temaki.description: A masterpiece of the culinary arts, this sushi nourishes the body, mind, and soul. Temaki is a large cone-shaped piece of nori on the outside and the ingredients spilling out the wide end. A typical temaki is about 10 centimetres long, and is eaten with fingers because it is too awkward to pick it up with chopsticks.
LanguageData.VCE_Futomaki.label: futomaki (lavish)
LanguageData.VCE_Futomaki.description: A masterpiece of the culinary arts, this sushi nourishes the body, mind, and soul. Futomaki is a large cylindrical piece, usually with nori on the outside. A typical futomaki is five to six centimetres in diameter. They are often made with two, three, or more fillings that are chosen for their complementary tastes and colors.
LanguageData.VCE_Gunkanmaki.label: gunkanmaki (gourmet)
LanguageData.VCE_Gunkanmaki.description: A culinary work of art, characterized by refined, even elaborate preparation and presentation of an aesthetically balanced, albeit low quantity sushi. Gunkanmaki is a special type of nigirizushi: an oval, hand-formed clump of sushi rice that has a strip of nori wrapped around its perimeter to form a vessel that is filled with some soft, loose or fine-chopped ingredient that requires the confinement of nori such as roe.
LanguageData.VCE_Oshizushi.label: oshizushi (gourmet)
LanguageData.VCE_Oshizushi.description: A culinary work of art, characterized by refined, even elaborate preparation and presentation of an aesthetically balanced, albeit low quantity sushi. In oshizushi, a block-shaped piece is formed using a wooden mold. The chef lines the bottom of the mold with the toppings, covers them with sushi rice, and then presses the lid of the mold down to create a compact, rectilinear block. The block is removed from the mold and then cut into bite-sized pieces.
